job.title: je
job.description:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "JobPosting", "datePosted": "2021-08-27T05:11:34.000Z", "description": "

Ascenium (www.ascenium.com) is building a new class of processor and recruiting for multiple Compiler Engineers/Architects. In this role, you will be a key member of our Core Engineering Team. This is a ground floor opportunity as Ascenium just raised a $16M series A round. You can follow the recent coverage about Ascenium in THE NEXT PLATFORM newsletter (https://www.nextplatform.com/2021/07/12/gutting-decades-of-architecture-to-build-a-new-kind-of-processor/). If you want to be part of a top-tier team that is building \u201cWhat\u2019s next\u201d in high performance processors, you will enjoy this role.  


Job Description

  • Design, develop, and enhance different components of the compiler
  • Benchmark and analyze output produced by optimizing compiler, and quantify results (analyze performance, code size, and key other compiler metrics)
  • Develop and execute benchmark and test scenarios for compilers
  • Collaborate with the HW design team to co-optimize compiler strategy  
  • Build custom front-end and back-end LLVM passes


Qualifications

  • BS or MS degree in Computer Science, Computer Engineering, Electrical Engineering, or related field of study
  • Minimum 3+ years of working experience with LLVM/compilers; Proven ability to design/architect compiler frameworks; Knowledge of LLVM flow, front-end and back-end compiler techniques; Strong background in debugging technologies, code generation, program analysis, and compiler optimizations
  • Experience in C++ programming, and software design skills, including debugging, performance analysis, and test design
  • Knowledge of contemporary of CPU and GPU Compute architectures
  • Experience and proficiency with code versioning systems (GitHub)
  • Familiarity with hand-written assembly optimizations (especially math-related)
  • Experience in constraint satisfaction problem-solving techniques, modeling, and simulation tools
  • Hardware background / familiarity with Verilog is a plus, but not mandatory
  • Ideally have public LLVM repository contributions
